issues.description: The problem statement and solution expect a class named Meal that is fully implemented (constructor Meal(String, String[]) and getters). The template repository, however, does not provide an implemented Meal class (Meal.java is empty) and instead contains an Order class with the same shape. This naming/availability mismatch will confuse students: the statement says Meal is provided, but the template doesn't include it and includes a differently-named class (Order). Students may be uncertain whether to implement Meal themselves or adapt to Order, and the provided Main in the template references Order in commented code while the problem text and solution use Meal.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template with the problem statement: provide a fully implemented Meal class in the template (constructor Meal(String, String[]) and getters) as described (you can copy the implementation from the solution). Remove or rename the Order class from the template (or explicitly document why Order exists and how it maps to Meal). Also update the template Main to reference Meal consistently so students are not misled by conflicting class names.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution repository use the class name Meal to represent a prepared dish (problem: 'Meal' class described as fully implemented; solution: Meal.java exists). However, the template repository does not provide Meal.java and instead provides a class named Order with the same fields and methods (name, ingredients). This naming mismatch (Meal vs Order) creates a direct mapping barrier: students reading the problem will look for a Meal class in the template, may be confused by the presence of Order, and could either attempt to rename or duplicate types incorrectly. This is an unintentional identifier naming inconsistency rather than a purposeful pedagogical variation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the identifier across artifacts. E.g., rename the template's Order class and file to Meal (class Meal { ... } in Meal.java) and update any references (Main, other template code) accordingly so the template provides Meal as described in the problem. Alternatively, if Order is intended, update the problem statement and solution to consistently use Order. Prefer making the template class name Meal to match the problem statement and solution implementation.
